item.title: Big win for Japan’s prime minister is good news for the U.S.
item.description: Sanae Takaichi shows that standing up to China pays politically.

item.title: The only way to ensure diversity of thought on college campuses
item.description: Readers on academic freedom and tax season woes.

item.title: The cost of Trump’s madman theory on tariffs
item.description: The president’s erratic nature can be a strength, but it’s also his biggest liability.

item.title: China’s ill-fated gambit to dethrone the dollar
item.description: The only way the U.S. dollar loses its primacy is self-sabotage.

item.title: The Epstein files release is an earthquake. Just not in Washington.
item.description: The fallout in the U.S. has been in the court of public opinion. In Britain, serious repercussions.

item.title: Another ludicrous canceling of a name from the past
item.description: Shaming the dead is an asinine culture warriors’ pastime. Now it’s the great diarist Samuel Pepys’s turn.

item.title: Brass-knuckled hypocrisy in Virginia
item.description: Voters will get a chance to reject anti-democratic gamesmanship in an April referendum.

item.title: Tariffs vs. the working class
item.description: The biggest winner of a trade war is the swamp.

item.title: Lincoln as you’ve never known him
item.description: Matthew Pinsker reveals how the 16th president carefully built a partisan base essential to his rise.

item.title: Bad Bunny is a free-market success story
item.description: He’s performing because a massive audience loves his music.

item.title: The regime in Cuba does not have the cards
item.description: The only thing for the United States to negotiate with dictator Miguel Díaz-Canel is when to step down.

item.title: A cover-up in Los Angeles
item.description: Karen Bass denies ordering a report on last year’s fires to be watered down.
